commits.message:
feat: add `MsgAddBsnRewards` handler and opt in BSNs consumer into F1 reward distribution (#1359)

- Adds new `MsgAddBsnRewards` to `x/btcstaking`. The reason to create in
the btcstaking instead of incentives is that we need to collect fp
commission data and consumer to get the babylon commission, so
incentives would need to import both btcstaking and btcstkconsumer,
besides the btcstaking already imports the incentives to give out
refundable msgs
- Integrates the voting power distribution events in finality to send
BTC delegations from BSN `activate/unbond` to incentives reward tracker
directly, without adding it to the babylon icentives block height event
queue
- New module account `ModAccCommissionCollectorBSN` used to isolate and
later manage the babylon commission over rewards attributed to BSNs

## What is misssing?

- [x] Tests to check changes in `x/finality/keeper/power_dist_change.go`
- [x] Add app driver tests
   - [x] BSN rewards calculation
- [x] add rewards to BSN Finality provider that never had voting power
- [x] add rewads to BSN FP that once had voting power but had his entire
stake unbonded
- [ ] e2e test for BSN rewards

(cherry picked from commit c93f250243cce816d6c36d85cd59f4302fbf5b94)

fix: set timezone on restake into score based product (#134)

Try setting timezone on restaking into score based products to prevent
errors like this:

https://nearblocks.io/ru/txns/9m56rPBTVYMhrxpucknWkBXqC9z2c91WzHZ88sEJvpin?tab=execution

This kind of errors occurs when a user had never created score based
jars before restaking.

fix: check cache update date on claim from score based jars (#135)

Before migration, we map an Account to the new account model. During the
mapping the account's jars' cache is being recalculated. But score based
jars' scores stay as is. It causes double claim on the first claim after
migration.
Example tx history:
https://nearblocks.io/ru/address/6b426d0c7fe5e718d9afeb89dcd8d78f6b6de41719db3f4fd3dd99409fedb2ec

I added a check to filter out scores that were submitted earlier than
the cache had been updated.

https://nearblocks.io/txns/7JSDLqrd33vQu1kigx9SkrpSVAA2cLr4jBNyKEvfpTGX

regular on-chain calls.

commits.message:
eth: fix canonical chain state inconsistency in checkpoint verifier

Add fallback logic to find potentialcommon ancestor using future milestones when
no whitelisted milestone exists in the current chain. Such scenario usually happens in a devnet.
This prevents nodes from getting stuck on wrong forks during milestone verification.

The issue occurs when nodes are on a fork and receive a new milestone:
- Existing logic only checks whitelisted milestones in current chain
- If current chain has no whitelisted milestones, rewind defaults to milestone start-1
- This can leave nodes on wrong fork instead of finding actual common ancestor

New logic adds findCommonAncestorWithFutureMilestones() which:
- Reads future milestone list from database (contains previously failed milestones)
- Searches from newest to oldest milestone to find matches with local chain
- Returns matching milestone block number to minimize rewind distance
- Falls back to calculated target block if no matches found

Signed-off-by: gopherorg <gopherworld@icloud.com>
Co-authored-by: Manav Darji <manavdarji.india@gmail.com>

Refactor and optimise commit interrupt (#1570)

Use a simple atomic flag for handling commit interrupt instead of using context based timeout. Internal benchmarks revealed that checking for `context.Done()` for every OPCODE leads to 40% CPU usage (out of the total CPU used in block building loop) which is not very optimal. Instead of context, a pointer to this atomic flag is passed and is toggled when the block building time is completed to interrupt. 

This also allows us to simply the use of commit interrupt and the worker - evm interaction.

This PR adds some features to make input in the `neo-cli` more user-friendly:

1. The help command outputs more information:
For example:
```
neo> help cancel
You can call this command like this:
	cancel --txid UInt256 [ --sender UInt160 ] [ --signerAccounts UInt160[] ]
Parameters for command `cancel`:
	txid: UInt256 (required)
	sender: UInt160 (optional, default: null)
